Joint Device Scheduling and Resource Allocation for Latency Constrained Wireless Federated Learning

Wenqi Shi, Sheng Zhou, , Zhisheng Niu, , Miao Jiang, and Lu Geng This work is sponsored in part by the National Key R&D Program of China 2018YFB1800800 and 2018YFB0105005, the Nature Science Foundation of China (No. 61871254, No. 91638204, No. 61861136003), and Hitachi Ltd. Part of this work has been accepted in IEEE ICC 2020 [1]. (corresponding author: Sheng Zhou)W. Shi, S. Zhou, and Z. Niu are with the Beijing National Research Center for Information Science and Technology, Department of Electronic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China (e-mail: swq17@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn; sheng.zhou@tsinghua.edu.cn; niuzhs@tsinghua.edu.cn).M. Jiang and L. Geng are with Hitachi (China) Research & Development Cooperation, Beijing 100190, China (e-mail: miaojiang@hitachi.cn; lgeng@hitachi.cn).
Abstract

In federated learning (FL), devices contribute to the global training by uploading their local model updates via wireless channels. Due to limited computation and communication resources, device scheduling is crucial to the convergence rate of FL. In this paper, we propose a joint device scheduling and resource allocation policy to maximize the model accuracy within a given total training time budget for latency constrained wireless FL. A lower bound on the reciprocal of the training performance loss, in terms of the number of training rounds and the number of scheduled devices per round, is derived. Based on the bound, the accuracy maximization problem is solved by decoupling it into two sub-problems. First, given the scheduled devices, the optimal bandwidth allocation suggests allocating more bandwidth to the devices with worse channel conditions or weaker computation capabilities. Then, a greedy device scheduling algorithm is introduced, which in each step selects the device consuming the least updating time obtained by the optimal bandwidth allocation, until the lower bound begins to increase, meaning that scheduling more devices will degrade the model accuracy. Experiments show that the proposed policy outperforms state-of-the-art scheduling policies under extensive settings of data distributions and cell radius.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, wireless networks, resource allocation, scheduling, convergence analysis

I Introduction

According to Cisco’s estimation, nearly 850 zettabytes of data will be generated each year at the network edge by 2021 [2]. These valuable data can bring diverse artificial intelligence (AI) services to end users by leveraging deep learning techniques [3], which are developing rapidly in recent years. However, training AI models (typically deep neural networks) via conventional centralized training methods requires aggregating all raw data to a central server. Since uploading raw data via wireless channels can drain the wireless bandwidth and cause privacy issues when the raw data are uploaded to the central server [4], it is hardly practical to use conventional centralized training methods in wireless networks [5].

To address the aforementioned issues, researchers have proposed a new distributed model training framework called Federated Learning (FL) [6, 7]. A typical wireless FL system leverages the computation capabilities of multiple end devices, which are coordinated by a central controller, for example a base station (BS), to train a model in an iterative fashion [8]. In each iteration of FL (also known as a round), the participating devices use their local data to update the local models, and then the local models are sent to the BS for global model aggregation. By updating the model parameters locally, FL leverages both the data and computation capabilities distributed on devices, and hence can reduce the model training latency as well as preserving the data privacy. Therefore, FL becomes a promising technology for distributed data analysis and model training in wireless networks [9, 10], and has been used in many applications, for instance, resource allocation optimization in vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communications [11] and content recommendations for smartphones [12].

However, implementing FL in real wireless networks encounters several key challenges that have not been fully resolved yet. Due to the scarce spectrum resources and stringent training latency budget, only a limited number of devices are allowed to upload local models in each round, where the device scheduling policy becomes crucial and can affect the convergence rate of FL in two ways. On the one hand, in each round, the BS cannot perform the global model aggregation until all scheduled devices have finished updating their local models and uploading the local model updates. Therefore, straggler devices with limited computation capabilities or bad channel conditions can significantly slow down the model aggregation. As a result, scheduling more devices leads to a longer latency per round, due to the reduced bandwidth allocated to each scheduled device and a higher probability of having straggler devices. On the other hand, scheduling more devices increases the convergence rate w.r.t. the number of rounds [13, 14], and can potentially reduce the number of rounds required to attain the same accuracy. Therefore, if we look at the total training time, which is the number of rounds times the average latency per round, the device scheduling is essential and should be carefully optimized to balance the latency per round and the number of required rounds. Moreover, the scheduling policy should also adapt itself to the dynamic wireless environment.

Recently, implementing FL in wireless networks has received many research efforts. To reduce the uploading latency introduced by global model aggregation, novel analog aggregation techniques have been proposed in [15, 16, 17]. For analog aggregation, the scheduled devices concurrently transmit their local models via analog modulation in a wireless multiple-access channel, and thus the BS receives the aggregated model thanks to the waveform-superposition property. Although the uploading latency can be greatly reduced, stringent synchronization among devices is required. While for digital transmission based FL, the scheduled devices need to share the limited wireless resources and the resource allocation problems have been studied by a series of work. The authors of [18] adopt TDMA for the MAC layer, and jointly optimize the device CPU frequency, the transmission latency, and the local model accuracy to minimize the weighted sum of training latency and total device energy consumption. A similar FL system but with FDMA is considered in [19]. On the other hand, the frequency of global aggregation under heterogeneous resource constraints has been optimized in [20, 21]. In [18, 19, 20, 21], all devices are involved in each round, which is hardly feasible in practical wireless FL applications due to the limited wireless bandwidth. Another series of work proposes to use device scheduling to optimize the convergence rate of FL. A heuristic scheduling policy that jointly considers the channel states and the importance of local updated models, is proposed in [22]. However, the proposed scheduling policy is only evaluated by experiments and the convergence performance cannot be theoretically guaranteed. A greedy scheduling policy is proposed in [23] that schedules as many devices as possible within a given deadline for each round. Nevertheless, the deadline is chosen through experiments and can hardly be adapted to dynamic channels and device computation capabilities. In [24], the authors exploit an intuition that the convergence rate of FL increases linearly with the number of scheduled devices, and accordingly an energy-efficient joint bandwidth allocation and scheduling policy is proposed. The relation between the number of rounds required to attain a certain accuracy and the scheduling policy is derived in [25], and three basic scheduling policies, namely random scheduling, round-robin, and proportional fair, are compared. However, due to the complicated relation between the number of rounds required to attain a certain accuracy and the per round latency, the convergence rate w.r.t. the number of rounds obtained by [25] cannot be directly transformed into the convergence rate w.r.t. time. The authors of [26] jointly optimize the uplink resource block allocation and transmission power to maximize the asymptotic convergence performance of FL, while the performance can hardly be guaranteed for latency constrained wireless FL applications. Therefore, the model accuracy within certain training time budgets (i.e., convergence rate w.r.t. time), which is critical for latency constrained FL applications [27, 28], has not been addressed yet.

In this paper, we aim to optimize the convergence rate of FL w.r.t. time rather than the number of rounds. Specifically, we formulate a joint bandwidth allocation and scheduling problem to maximize the accuracy of the trained model, and further decouple the problem into two sub-problems, i.e., bandwidth allocation and device scheduling. For the bandwidth allocation problem, assuming a given set of scheduled devices, the implicit optimal solution that minimizes the latency of the current round is first obtained, and an efficient binary search algorithm is proposed to numerically get the optimal bandwidth allocation and the corresponding round latency. For the device scheduling problem, by relaxing the objective into minimizing the upper bound of the loss function based on a derived convergence bound that incorporates device scheduling, we design a greedy algorithm that adds devices one by one with the shortest updating time to the scheduled devices set, until the convergence bound begins to increase, meaning that scheduling more devices will reduce the convergence rate. Our main contributions are summarized as follows.

  • •

    We theoretically bound the impact of the device scheduling in each round, based on which the convergence analysis from [20] is extended to derive a convergence bound of FL in terms of the number of rounds and the number of scheduled devices. The bound applies for non-independent and identically distributed (non-i.i.d.) local datasets and an arbitrary number of scheduled devices in each round.

  • •

    The obtained convergence bound quantifies the trade-off between the latency per round and the number of required rounds to attain a fixed accuracy, and thus the device scheduling can be accordingly optimized to maximize the convergence rate of FL.

  • •

    Using the obtained convergence bound, we design a device scheduling policy according to the learned loss function characteristics, gradient characteristics, and system dynamics in real time, in order to minimize the loss function value under a given training time budget.

  • •

    Our experiments show that the optimal number of scheduled devices increases with the non-i.i.d. level of local datasets, and the proposed scheduling policy adapts to non-i.i.d. local datasets and can achieve near-optimal performance. Moreover, the proposed scheduling policy outperforms several state-of-the-art scheduling policies in terms of the highest achievable accuracy within the total training time budget.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the system model and formulate the convergence rate optimization problem. We derive a convergence bound and approximately solve the problem in Section III. The experiment results are shown in Section IV and we conclude the paper in Section V.

II-A Federated Learning over Wireless Networks

FL uses an iterative approach to solve problem (1), and each round, indexed by k𝑘k, contains the following 3 steps.

  1. 1.

    The BS first decides to schedule which devices to participate in the current round, and the set of scheduled devices in round k𝑘k is denoted by ΠksubscriptΠ𝑘\Pi_{k}. Then the BS broadcasts the current global model 𝒘k−1𝚷[k−1]superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘1subscript𝚷delimited-[]𝑘1\bm{w}_{k-1}^{\bm{\Pi}_{[k-1]}} to all scheduled devices, where 𝚷[k−1]≜[Π1,Π2,…,Πk−1]≜subscript𝚷delimited-[]𝑘1subscriptΠ1subscriptΠ2…subscriptΠ𝑘1\bm{\Pi}_{[k-1]}\triangleq[\Pi_{1},\Pi_{2},\dots,\Pi_{k-1}] denotes the historical scheduling decisions up to the (k−1)𝑘1(k-1)-th round.

  2. 2.

    Each scheduled device i∈Πk𝑖subscriptΠ𝑘i\in\Pi_{k} receives the global model (i.e., 𝒘i,k​(0)←𝒘k−1𝚷[k−1]←subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘1subscript𝚷delimited-[]𝑘1\bm{w}_{i,k}(0)\leftarrow\bm{w}_{k-1}^{\bm{\Pi}_{[k-1]}}) and updates its local model by applying the gradient descent algorithm on its local dataset:

    𝒘i,k​(j+1)=𝒘i,k​(j)−η​∇Fi​(𝒘i,k​(j)),j=0,1,…,τ−1,formulae-sequencesubscript𝒘𝑖𝑘𝑗1subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘𝑗𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘𝑗𝑗01…𝜏1\bm{w}_{i,k}(j+1)=\bm{w}_{i,k}(j)-\eta\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i,k}(j)),\ j=0,1,\dots,\tau-1, (2)

    where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate. In practice, the local dataset may have thousands or even millions of data samples, making the gradient descent impractical. Therefore, stochastic gradient descent (SGD), which can be regarded as a stochastic approximation of gradient descent, is widely used as a substitution. In SGD, the gradient ∇Fi​(𝒘i,k​(j))∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘𝑗\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i,k}(j)) is computed on 𝒟b,isubscript𝒟𝑏𝑖\mathcal{D}_{b,i}, a randomly sampled subset from 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, where 𝒟b,isubscript𝒟𝑏𝑖\mathcal{D}_{b,i} is called mini-batch and di=|𝒟b,i|subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝒟𝑏𝑖d_{i}=|\mathcal{D}_{b,i}| is called batch size. The local model update is repeated for τ𝜏\tau times and τ𝜏\tau is considered as a fixed system parameter. Then the updated local model 𝒘i,k​(τ)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘𝜏\bm{w}_{i,k}(\tau) is uploaded to the BS. In the following part of the paper, we use 𝒘i,ksubscript𝒘𝑖𝑘\bm{w}_{i,k} to denote 𝒘i,k​(τ)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘𝜏\bm{w}_{i,k}(\tau) unless otherwise specified.

  3. 3.

    After receiving all the uploaded models, the BS aggregates them (i.e., weighted averages the uploaded local models according to the size of local datasets) to obtain a new global model:

    𝒘k𝚷[k]=∑i∈ΠkDi​𝒘i,k∑i∈ΠkDi.superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘subscript𝚷delimited-[]𝑘subscript𝑖subscriptΠ𝑘subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘subscript𝑖subscriptΠ𝑘subscript𝐷𝑖\bm{w}_{k}^{\bm{\Pi}_{[k]}}=\frac{\sum_{i\in\Pi_{k}}D_{i}\bm{w}_{i,k}}{\sum_{i\in\Pi_{k}}D_{i}}. (3)

II-B Latency Model

We consider an arbitrary round k𝑘k, the total latency of the k𝑘k-th round consists of the following parts:

II-B1 Computation Latency

To characterize the randomness of the computation latency of local model update, we use the shifted exponential distribution[29, 30]:

ℙ​[ti,kcp<t]={1−e−μiτ​di​(t−ai​τ​di), t≥ai​τ​di,0, otherwise,ℙdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑘cp𝑡cases1superscript𝑒subscript𝜇𝑖𝜏subscript𝑑𝑖𝑡subscript𝑎𝑖𝜏subscript𝑑𝑖, t≥aiτdi,0, otherwise,\mathbb{P}[t_{i,k}^{\text{cp}}<t]=\begin{cases}{1-e^{-\frac{\mu_{i}}{\tau d_{i}}(t-a_{i}\tau d_{i})}}&{\text{, $t\geq a_{i}\tau d_{i}$,}}\\ 0&\text{, otherwise,}\end{cases} (4)

where ai>0subscript𝑎𝑖0a_{i}>0 and μi>0subscript𝜇𝑖0\mu_{i}>0 are parameters that indicate the maximum and fluctuation of the computation capabilities, respectively. We assume that aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} and μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} stay constant throughout the whole training process. Moreover, we ignore the computation latency of the model aggregation at the BS, due to the relatively stronger computation capability of the BS and low complexity of the model aggregation.

II-B2 Communication Latency

Regarding the local model uploading phase of the scheduled devices, we consider an FDMA system with total bandwidth B𝐵B. The bandwidth allocated to device i𝑖i is denoted by γi,k​Bsubscript𝛾𝑖𝑘𝐵\gamma_{i,k}B, where γi,ksubscript𝛾𝑖𝑘\gamma_{i,k} is the allocation ratio that satisfies ∑i=1Mγi,k≤1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝛾𝑖𝑘1\sum_{i=1}^{M}\gamma_{i,k}\leq 1 and 0≤γi,k≤10subscript𝛾𝑖𝑘10\leq\gamma_{i,k}\leq 1. Therefore, the achievable transmission rate (bits/s) can be written as ri,k=γi,k​B​log2​(1+Pi​hi,k2γi,k​B​N0)subscript𝑟𝑖𝑘subscript𝛾𝑖𝑘𝐵subscriptlog21subscript𝑃𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑘2subscript𝛾𝑖𝑘𝐵subscript𝑁0r_{i,k}=\gamma_{i,k}B\text{log}_{2}\left(1+\frac{P_{i}h_{i,k}^{2}}{\gamma_{i,k}BN_{0}}\right), where Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} denotes the transmit power of device i𝑖i, that stays constant with different rounds, and hi,ksubscriptℎ𝑖𝑘h_{i,k} denotes the corresponding channel gain, and N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the noise power density. Thus the communication latency of device i𝑖i is

ti,kcm=Sri,k,superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑘cm𝑆subscript𝑟𝑖𝑘t_{i,k}^{\text{cm}}=\frac{S}{r_{i,k}}, (5)

where S𝑆S denotes the size of w→i,ksubscript→𝑤𝑖𝑘\vec{w}_{i,k}, in bits. Since the transmit power of the BS is much higher than that of the devices and the whole downlink bandwidth is used by BS to broadcast the model, here we ignore the latency of broadcasting the global model.

Due to the synchronous model aggregation of FL, the total latency per round tkround​(Πk)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘roundsubscriptΠ𝑘t_{k}^{\text{round}}(\Pi_{k}) is determined by the slowest device among all the scheduled devices, i.e.,

II-C Problem Formulation

A joint bandwidth allocation and scheduling problem is formulated to optimize the convergence rate of FL w.r.t. time. Specifically, we use K𝐾K to denote the total number of rounds within the training time budget T𝑇T, and minimize the global loss function of 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}} within T𝑇T, where 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}} is the optimal model parameter that has the minimum global loss function value in the whole training process and defined as

𝒘~≜arg min𝒘∈{𝒘k𝚷[k]:k=1,2,…,K}​F​(𝒘).≜~𝒘𝒘conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘subscript𝚷delimited-[]𝑘𝑘12…𝐾arg min𝐹𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}}\triangleq\underset{\bm{w}\in\{\bm{w}_{k}^{\bm{\Pi}_{[k]}}:k=1,2,\dots,K\}}{\text{arg\,min}}F(\bm{w}). (7)

For simplicity, we use [K]delimited-[]𝐾[K] and [M]delimited-[]𝑀[M] to denote {1,2,…,K}12…𝐾\{1,2,\dots,K\} and {1,2,…,M}12…𝑀\{1,2,\dots,M\}, respectively. The optimization problem can be written as follows:

where 𝚷[K]=[Π1,Π2,…,ΠK]subscript𝚷delimited-[]𝐾subscriptΠ1subscriptΠ2…subscriptΠ𝐾\bm{\Pi}_{[K]}=[\Pi_{1},\Pi_{2},\dots,\Pi_{K}], 𝜸[K]≜[𝜸1,𝜸2,…,𝜸K]≜subscript𝜸delimited-[]𝐾subscript𝜸1subscript𝜸2…subscript𝜸𝐾\bm{\gamma}_{[K]}\triangleq[\bm{\gamma}_{1},\bm{\gamma}_{2},\dots,\bm{\gamma}_{K}] with 𝜸k≜[γ1,k,γ2,k,…,γM,k]≜subscript𝜸𝑘subscript𝛾1𝑘subscript𝛾2𝑘…subscript𝛾𝑀𝑘\bm{\gamma}_{k}\triangleq[\gamma_{1,k},\gamma_{2,k},\dots,\gamma_{M,k}], and 𝒕[K]round≜[t1round​(Π1),t2round​(Π2),…,tKround​(ΠK)]≜subscriptsuperscript𝒕rounddelimited-[]𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝑡round1subscriptΠ1subscriptsuperscript𝑡round2subscriptΠ2…subscriptsuperscript𝑡round𝐾subscriptΠ𝐾\bm{t}^{\text{round}}_{[K]}\triangleq[t^{\text{round}}_{1}(\Pi_{1}),t^{\text{round}}_{2}(\Pi_{2}),\dots,t^{\text{round}}_{K}(\Pi_{K})].

To solve P1, we need to know how K𝐾K and Π→[K]subscript→Πdelimited-[]𝐾\vec{\Pi}_{[K]} affect the loss function of the final global model, i.e., F​(𝒘~)𝐹~𝒘F(\tilde{\bm{w}}). Since it is almost impossible to find an exact analytical expression of F​(𝒘~)𝐹~𝒘F(\tilde{\bm{w}}) w.r.t. K𝐾K and Π→[K]subscript→Πdelimited-[]𝐾\vec{\Pi}_{[K]}, we turn to bound F​(𝒘~)𝐹~𝒘F(\tilde{\bm{w}}) in terms of K𝐾K and Π→[K]subscript→Πdelimited-[]𝐾\vec{\Pi}_{[K]}. While in our problem, the local computation latency ti,kcpsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑘cpt_{i,k}^{\text{cp}} and wireless channel state hi,ksubscriptℎ𝑖𝑘h_{i,k} can vary with different k𝑘k, thus the optimal scheduling policy Π→[K]∗subscriptsuperscript→Πdelimited-[]𝐾\vec{\Pi}^{*}_{[K]} can be non-stationary. Moreover, due to the iterative nature of FL, the global model is related to the scheduling policies of all past rounds. As a result, it is very hard to bound F​(𝒘~)𝐹~𝒘F(\tilde{\bm{w}}) under a non-stationary scheduling policy.

In the next section, P1 is solved in the following way. First, we decouple P1 into two sub-problems, namely device scheduling and bandwidth allocation. Then given the scheduled devices, the bandwidth allocation problem is analytically solved. Further, based on the optimal bandwidth allocation, and a derived convergence bound of FL under a stationary random scheduling policy, we approximately solve the device scheduling problem with a joint device scheduling and bandwidth allocation algorithm.

III Joint Device Scheduling and Bandwidth Allocation

P1 is decoupled as follows. First, given the scheduling policy of the k𝑘k-th round (i.e., ΠksubscriptΠ𝑘\Pi_{k}), the bandwidth allocation problem of the k𝑘k-th round can be written as follows:

III-A Bandwidth Allocation

The optimal solution of P2 can be obtained using the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

The optimal bandwidth allocation of P2 is as follows

Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

Due to the Lambert-W function in (9), in which the argument is related to tk∗​(Πk)subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑘subscriptΠ𝑘t^{*}_{k}(\Pi_{k}) via Γi,ksubscriptΓ𝑖𝑘\Gamma_{i,k}, we cannot analytically solve (9) to derive tk∗​(Πk)subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑘subscriptΠ𝑘t^{*}_{k}(\Pi_{k}). Thus a binary search algorithm (Alg. 1) is proposed to get the optimal value of P2 numerically. Begin with the target value t𝑡t that equals to the upper bound of the initial searching region [tlow,tup]subscript𝑡lowsubscript𝑡up[t_{\text{low}},t_{\text{up}}], we iteratively compute the required bandwidth for the current target value t𝑡t by substituting tk∗​(Πk)=tsubscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑘subscriptΠ𝑘𝑡t^{*}_{k}(\Pi_{k})=t into (8) (step 3), and derive the total required bandwidth allocation ratio (step 4). The searching region is halved and the smaller half will be retained if the bandwidth is surplus (steps 7-8), while the larger half will be retained if the bandwidth is deficit (steps 9-10). The searching terminates when the given precision requirement (i.e., ε𝜀\varepsilon) is satisfied (steps 5-6), and thus the complexity of Alg. 1 is on the order of 𝒪​(|Πk|​log2​(tupε))𝒪subscriptΠ𝑘subscriptlog2subscript𝑡up𝜀\mathcal{O}\left(|\Pi_{k}|\text{log}_{2}\left(\frac{t_{\text{up}}}{\varepsilon}\right)\right).

III-B Convergence Analysis

Before the convergence analysis, we first introduce some notations, as shown in Fig. 1. For the stationary random scheduling policy ΠΠ\Pi, we use 𝒘kΠsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘Π\bm{w}_{k}^{\Pi} to denote 𝒘k𝚷[k]superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘subscript𝚷delimited-[]𝑘\bm{w}_{k}^{\bm{\Pi}_{[k]}}. Two auxiliary model parameter vectors are introduced, where 𝒘ksubscript𝒘𝑘\bm{w}_{k} (k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1) is used to denote the model parameter vector that is synchronized with 𝒘k−1Πsubscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝑘1\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k-1} at the beginning of the k𝑘k-th round, and is updated by scheduling all devices (i.e., w→k≜∑i∈ℳDi​𝒘i,k∑i∈ℳDi≜subscript→𝑤𝑘subscript𝑖ℳsubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘subscript𝑖ℳsubscript𝐷𝑖\vec{w}_{k}\triangleq\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{M}}D_{i}\bm{w}_{i,k}}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{M}}D_{i}}) in the k𝑘k-th round. While 𝒗ksubscript𝒗𝑘\bm{v}_{k} (k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1) is used to denote the model parameter vector that is synchronized with 𝒘k−1Πsubscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝑘1\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k-1} at the beginning of the k𝑘k-th round, and is updated by centralized gradient descent. In the centralized gradient descent procedure of the k𝑘k-th round, 𝒗ksubscript𝒗𝑘\bm{v}_{k} is updated according to 𝒗k←𝒗k−η​∇F​(𝒗k)←subscript𝒗𝑘subscript𝒗𝑘𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝒗𝑘\bm{v}_{k}\leftarrow\bm{v}_{k}-\eta\nabla F(\bm{v}_{k}) for τ𝜏\tau times.

To facilitate the analysis, we make the following assumptions on the loss functions F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot).

Assumption 1.

We assume the following for the loss functions of all devices:

  • •

    Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F_{i}(\bm{w}) is convex.

  • •

    Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F_{i}(\bm{w}) is ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, i.e., ∥Fi​(𝒘)−Fi​(𝒘′)∥≤ρ​∥𝒘−𝒘′∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘′𝜌delimited-∥∥𝒘superscript𝒘′\left\lVert F_{i}(\bm{w})-F_{i}(\bm{w}^{\prime})\right\rVert\leq\rho\left\lVert\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime}\right\rVert, for any 𝒘,𝒘′𝒘superscript𝒘′\bm{w},\bm{w}^{\prime}.

  • •

    Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F_{i}(\bm{w}) is β𝛽\beta-smooth, i.e., ∥∇Fi​(𝒘)−∇Fi​(𝒘′)∥≤β​∥𝒘−𝒘′∥delimited-∥∥∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘′𝛽delimited-∥∥𝒘superscript𝒘′\left\lVert\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{\prime})\right\rVert\leq\beta\left\lVert\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime}\right\rVert, for any 𝒘,𝒘′𝒘superscript𝒘′\bm{w},\bm{w}^{\prime}.

  • •

    For any i𝑖i and 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}, the difference between the local gradient and the global gradient can be bounded by ∥∇Fi​(𝒘)−∇F​(𝒘)∥≤δidelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘∇𝐹𝒘subscript𝛿𝑖\left\lVert\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})-\nabla F(\bm{w})\right\rVert\leq\delta_{i}, and define δ≜∑iDi​δiD≜𝛿subscript𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖𝐷\delta\triangleq\frac{\sum_{i}D_{i}\delta_{i}}{D}.

These assumptions are widely used in the literature of convergence analysis for FL [20, 25, 19, 26], although the loss functions of some machine learning models (e.g., neural network) do not fully satisfy them, especially the convexity assumption. However, our experiment results show that the proposed scheduling policy works well even for the neural network.

To begin with, we derive the upper bound of the difference between the global model aggregated form a stationary random scheduling policy ΠΠ\Pi (i.e., 𝒘kΠsubscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝑘\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k}) and 𝒘ksubscript𝒘𝑘\bm{w}_{k}.

Definition 1.

We define a policy ΠΠ\Pi as a stationary random scheduling policy if and only if ΠΠ\Pi is a size-|Π|Π|\Pi| subset, which is uniformly random sampled from all devices ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, and |Π|Π|\Pi| stays constant during the whole training process.

Theorem 2.

For any k𝑘k and stationary random scheduling policy ΠΠ\Pi (|Π|≥1Π1|\Pi|\geq 1), we have

𝔼​{F​(𝒘kΠ)−F​(𝒘k)}𝔼𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝑘𝐹subscript𝒘𝑘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k})-F(\bm{w}_{k})\right\} ≤M−|Π||Π|⋅β​∑i=1M∑j=1M(Di2​Dj2​(gi2​(τ)+gj2​(τ)))2​M​(M−1)​Dmin2​D2⏟A≜B​(Π),absent⋅𝑀ΠΠsubscript⏟𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖2𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑗2𝜏2𝑀𝑀1superscriptsubscript𝐷min2superscript𝐷2𝐴≜𝐵Π\displaystyle\leq\frac{M-|\Pi|}{|\Pi|}\cdot\underbrace{\frac{\beta\sum_{i=1}^{M}\sum_{j=1}^{M}\left(D_{i}^{2}D_{j}^{2}\left(g_{i}^{2}(\tau)+g_{j}^{2}(\tau)\right)\right)}{2M(M-1)D_{\rm min}^{2}D^{2}}}_{A}\triangleq B(\Pi), (10)

where Dmin≜mini∈ℳ​Di≜subscript𝐷minsubscriptmin𝑖ℳsubscript𝐷𝑖D_{\rm min}\triangleq{\rm min}_{i\in\mathcal{M}}D_{i}, gi​(x)≜δiβ​((η​β+1)x−1)≜subscript𝑔𝑖𝑥subscript𝛿𝑖𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1𝑥1g_{i}(x)\triangleq\frac{\delta_{i}}{\beta}\left((\eta\beta+1)^{x}-1\right), and the expectation is taken over the randomness of ΠΠ\Pi.

Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

Note that we always have the learning rate η>0𝜂0\eta>0, otherwise the gradient descent procedure becomes trivial. We also have β>0𝛽0\beta>0 and δi>0subscript𝛿𝑖0\delta_{i}>0, otherwise the loss function and its gradient become trivial. Therefore, gi​(x)>0subscript𝑔𝑖𝑥0g_{i}(x)>0 for x=1,2,…,τ𝑥12…𝜏x=1,2,\dots,\tau, and thus A>0𝐴0A>0, where A𝐴A is defined in (10). It is obvious that A𝐴A is not related to ΠΠ\Pi, and M−|Π||Π|𝑀ΠΠ\frac{M-|\Pi|}{|\Pi|} decreases with |Π|Π|\Pi|. Therefore, scheduling fewer devices leads to a larger upper bound of 𝔼​{F​(𝒘kΠ)−F​(𝒘k)}𝔼𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝑘𝐹subscript𝒘𝑘\mathbb{E}\left\{F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k})-F(\bm{w}_{k})\right\}, as thus, a larger upper bound of 𝔼​{F​(𝒘kΠ)}𝔼𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝑘\mathbb{E}\left\{F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k})\right\}. This means that scheduling fewer devices slows down the convergence rate w.r.t. the number of rounds, which is consistent with conclusions from existing work [24, 23]. Furthermore, when Π=ℳΠℳ\Pi=\mathcal{M} (i.e., schedule all devices), B​(Π)𝐵ΠB(\Pi) achieves its lower bound zero, which is consistent with the definition of 𝒘ksubscript𝒘𝑘\bm{w}_{k}.,

Then, we can combine Theorem 2 with the convergence analysis in [20] to derive the following theorem, which bounds the difference between 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}} and 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*}. In Theorem 3, 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}}, defined in (7), is the optimal model parameter that has the minimum global loss function value in the whole training process, and 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*} is the true optimal model parameter that minimizes F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F(\bm{w}).

Theorem 3.

When η≤1β𝜂1𝛽\eta\leq\frac{1}{\beta} and ΠΠ\Pi is a stationary random scheduling policy, the difference between F​(𝐰~)𝐹~𝐰F(\tilde{\bm{w}}) and F​(𝐰∗)𝐹superscript𝐰F(\bm{w}^{*}) satisfies:

𝔼​{1F​(𝒘~)−F​(𝒘∗)}≥1ϵ0+ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π),𝔼1𝐹~𝒘𝐹superscript𝒘1subscriptitalic-ϵ0𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π\mathbb{E}\left\{\frac{1}{F(\tilde{\bm{w}})-F(\bm{w}^{*})}\right\}\geq\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}+\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)}, (11)

where ϵ0≜1+1+4​η​φ​K2​τ​(ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π))2​η​φ​K​τ≜subscriptitalic-ϵ0114𝜂𝜑superscript𝐾2𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π2𝜂𝜑𝐾𝜏\epsilon_{0}\triangleq\frac{1+\sqrt{1+4\eta\varphi K^{2}\tau\left(\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)\right)}}{2\eta\varphi K\tau}, φ≜ω​(1−β​η2)≜𝜑𝜔1𝛽𝜂2\varphi\triangleq\omega\left(1-\frac{\beta\eta}{2}\right), ω≜mink​1∥𝐰kΠ−𝐰∗∥≜𝜔subscriptmin𝑘1delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscript𝐰Π𝑘superscript𝐰\omega\triangleq{\rm{min}}_{k}\frac{1}{\left\lVert\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k}-\bm{w}^{*}\right\rVert}, h​(x)≜δβ​((η​β+1)x−1)−η​δ​x≜ℎ𝑥𝛿𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1𝑥1𝜂𝛿𝑥h(x)\triangleq\frac{\delta}{\beta}((\eta\beta+1)^{x}-1)-\eta\delta x, and the expectation is taken over the randomness of ΠΠ\Pi.

Proof.

See Appendix C. ∎

Theorem 3 quantifies the trade-off between the latency per round and the number of required rounds. Scheduling more devices increases the latency per round, and thus decreases the number of possible rounds within the given training time budget T𝑇T (i.e., K𝐾K), while a smaller K𝐾K can decrease the lower bound of 𝔼​{1F​(𝒘~)−F​(𝒘∗)}𝔼1𝐹~𝒘𝐹superscript𝒘\mathbb{E}\left\{\frac{1}{F(\tilde{\bm{w}})-F(\bm{w}^{*})}\right\}. At the same time, scheduling more devices decreases the value of B​(Π)𝐵ΠB(\Pi) as shown by Theorem 2, while a smaller B​(Π)𝐵ΠB(\Pi) can increase the lower bound of 𝔼​{1F​(𝒘~)−F​(𝒘∗)}𝔼1𝐹~𝒘𝐹superscript𝒘\mathbb{E}\left\{\frac{1}{F(\tilde{\bm{w}})-F(\bm{w}^{*})}\right\}. As a result, the scheduling policy should be carefully optimized to balance the trade-off between the latency per round and the number of required rounds, in order to minimize the loss function of the optimal global model (i.e., F​(𝒘~)𝐹~𝒘F(\tilde{\bm{w}})).

III-C Device Scheduling Algorithm

In real wireless networks, the local computation latency ti,kcpsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑘cpt_{i,k}^{\text{cp}} and wireless channel state hi,ksubscriptℎ𝑖𝑘h_{i,k} can vary in different rounds k𝑘k, due to the fluctuation of the wireless channels and device computation capabilities. Therefore, at the k𝑘k-th round, ti,k′cpsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖superscript𝑘′cpt_{i,k^{\prime}}^{\text{cp}} and hi,k′subscriptℎ𝑖superscript𝑘′h_{i,k^{\prime}} for k′>ksuperscript𝑘′𝑘k^{\prime}>k are unknown, making the constraint (C3.1) in P3 intractable because of the unknown tk′∗​(Πk′)subscriptsuperscript𝑡superscript𝑘′subscriptΠsuperscript𝑘′t^{*}_{k^{\prime}}(\Pi_{k^{\prime}}) for k′>ksuperscript𝑘′𝑘k^{\prime}>k. To address this issue, we solve P3 myopically. Consider an arbitrary round k𝑘k and an arbitrary scheduling policy ΠksubscriptΠ𝑘\Pi_{k}, we approximately view that ΠksubscriptΠ𝑘\Pi_{k} is used in the whole training process, and thus the number of total rounds can be approximated by K^=⌊Ttk∗​(Πk)⌋^𝐾𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑘subscriptΠ𝑘\hat{K}=\left\lfloor\frac{T}{t^{*}_{k}(\Pi_{k})}\right\rfloor, where ⌊⋅⌋⋅\lfloor\cdot\rfloor denotes floor function. Furthermore, for a given global loss function, F​(𝒘∗)𝐹superscript𝒘F(\bm{w}^{*}) is a constant, and thus minimizing F​(𝒘~)𝐹~𝒘F(\tilde{\bm{w}}) is equivalent to maximizing 1F​(𝒘~)−F​(𝒘∗)1𝐹~𝒘𝐹superscript𝒘\frac{1}{F(\tilde{\bm{w}})-F(\bm{w}^{*})}. Since the learning rate η𝜂\eta can be chosen small enough to satisfy η≤1β𝜂1𝛽\eta\leq\frac{1}{\beta}, the objective of P3 can be approximated by maximizing the lower bound of 𝔼​{1F​(𝒘~)−F​(𝒘∗)}𝔼1𝐹~𝒘𝐹superscript𝒘\mathbb{E}\left\{\frac{1}{F(\tilde{\bm{w}})-F(\bm{w}^{*})}\right\} according to Theorem 3, which is equivalent to minimizing the denominator of the right hand side of (11). Consequently, P3 can be approximated by the following myopic problem in each round:

minΠksubscriptΠ𝑘min\displaystyle\underset{\Pi_{k}}{\text{min}}\quad 1+1+4​η​φ​K^2​τ​(ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Πk))2​η​φ​K^​τ+ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Πk)114𝜂𝜑superscript^𝐾2𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵subscriptΠ𝑘2𝜂𝜑^𝐾𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵subscriptΠ𝑘\displaystyle\frac{1+\sqrt{1+4\eta\varphi\hat{K}^{2}\tau\left(\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi_{k})\right)}}{2\eta\varphi\hat{K}\tau}+\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi_{k}) (P4)
s.t. K^=⌊Ttk∗​(Πk)⌋,^𝐾𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑘subscriptΠ𝑘\displaystyle\hat{K}=\left\lfloor\frac{T}{t^{*}_{k}(\Pi_{k})}\right\rfloor, (C4.1)
Πk⊂ℳ.subscriptΠ𝑘ℳ\displaystyle\Pi_{k}\subset\mathcal{M}. (C4.2)

P4 is still a combinatorial optimization problem due to the constraint (C4.2), which is hard to solve. Therefore we propose a greedy algorithm (Alg. 2) to schedule devices. In steps 2-3 of Alg. 2, the round latency of scheduling each unscheduled device is given by Alg. 1, based on which we choose the device with the minimum latency into the scheduled devices set. Consequently, we initialize the value of the objective function of P4 in step 4. Then, a similar process is iteratively performed in steps 6-7, until the objective function of P4 starts to increase or all devices are scheduled. The complexity of Alg. 2 is on the order of 𝒪​(|ℳ|3)𝒪superscriptℳ3\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{M}|^{3}) (because of calling Alg. 1 for 𝒪​(|ℳ|2)𝒪superscriptℳ2\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{M}|^{2}) times), which is much more efficient than the naive brute force search algorithm on the order of 𝒪​(2|ℳ|)𝒪superscript2ℳ\mathcal{O}(2^{|\mathcal{M}|}).

However, due to the unknown optimal model 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w}^{*}, it is non-trivial to analytically estimate the value of φ𝜑\varphi, and thus we treat φ𝜑\varphi as a system parameter that remains fixed throughout the training process. It is shown in the experiments that a fixed φ𝜑\varphi performs well across different system settings like data distributions and cell radius, while the searching for an appropriate value of φ𝜑\varphi is not difficult as well.

III-D The Whole Policy

In this subsection, we propose the complete procedure of the wireless FL with our fast converge scheduling policy (as shown in Alg. 3), which enables the BS to schedule devices in real-time and minimizes the global loss function within the training time budget.

In Alg. 3, steps 1-2 are the initialization phase, initializing 𝒘0Πsuperscriptsubscript𝒘0Π\bm{w}_{0}^{\Pi}, 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}} for the global model, and ρ→^^→𝜌\hat{\vec{\rho}}, β→^^→𝛽\hat{\vec{\beta}}, δ→^^→𝛿\hat{\vec{\delta}}, which are used to record the real-time estimations of the convergence property parameters. In each round, Alg. 2 is called to obtain the device scheduling policy based on the estimated ρ→^^→𝜌\hat{\vec{\rho}}, β→^^→𝛽\hat{\vec{\beta}} and δ→^^→𝛿\hat{\vec{\delta}} (step 5). Then in step 6, Alg. 1 is called to obtain the optimal bandwidth allocation for scheduled devices and the corresponding round latency 111When the devices are updating the local models, they can send pilot signals to the edge server to estimate the channel and inform the edge server of their progress of local computation with low communication overhead. Therefore, perfect information of ti,kcpsubscriptsuperscript𝑡cp𝑖𝑘t^{\text{cp}}_{i,k} and hi,ksubscriptℎ𝑖𝑘h_{i,k} is assumed to be known unless otherwise specified.. We update the accumulated training latency and check if it exceeds the budget T𝑇T in steps 7-9. Despite the regular FL local update procedure (steps 13-14), each scheduled device i∈Πk𝑖subscriptΠ𝑘i\in\Pi_{k} also needs to estimate ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} and βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} based on the local loss and gradient of 𝒘k−1Πsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘1Π\bm{w}_{k-1}^{\Pi} and 𝒘i,ksubscript𝒘𝑖𝑘\bm{w}_{i,k} according to step 15. Then in step 16, the updated local models, the estimations, and the loss function values are sent to the BS. The BS receives the uploaded local models, based on which the global model is updated according to (3) (step 18), and updates the estimation records of ρ→^^→𝜌\hat{\vec{\rho}} and β→^^→𝛽\hat{\vec{\beta}} (step 19). We update 𝜹^^𝜹\hat{\bm{\delta}} in a similar way in steps 20-21 and update 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}} in steps 22-25. Note that Alg. 2 needs the estimated ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}, βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i}, and δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} for all devices to compute the convergence bound (according to step 7 in Alg. 2, and (10)), while only the devices that have been scheduled in the last round have the up-to-date estimations. To address this issue, for each device that has not been scheduled in the last round, we use the latest estimation in the past rounds to approximate the up-to-date estimation. Therefore, ρ→^^→𝜌\hat{\vec{\rho}}, β→^^→𝛽\hat{\vec{\beta}}, and δ→^^→𝛿\hat{\vec{\delta}} are used to record the estimations and estimate ρ^^𝜌\hat{\rho}, β^^𝛽\hat{\beta}, and δ^^𝛿\hat{\delta} according to step 4.

In an arbitrary round k𝑘k, the additional computational complexity of Alg. 3 at the BS compared to the conventional FL mainly consists of three parts: 1) the computational complexity of Alg. 2, which is 𝒪​(|ℳ|3)𝒪superscriptℳ3\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{M}|^{3}); 2) the computational complexity of Alg. 1, which is 𝒪​(|Πk|​log2​(tupε))𝒪subscriptΠ𝑘subscriptlog2subscript𝑡up𝜀\mathcal{O}\left(|\Pi_{k}|\text{log}_{2}\left(\frac{t_{\text{up}}}{\varepsilon}\right)\right); 3) the computational complexity of maintaining ρ→^^→𝜌\hat{\vec{\rho}}, β→^^→𝛽\hat{\vec{\beta}}, and δ→^^→𝛿\hat{\vec{\delta}}, which is 𝒪​(|Πk|)𝒪subscriptΠ𝑘\mathcal{O}(|\Pi_{k}|). Because |Πk|≤|ℳ|subscriptΠ𝑘ℳ|\Pi_{k}|\leq|\mathcal{M}|, the total additional computation complexity at the BS is 𝒪​(|ℳ|3)𝒪superscriptℳ3\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{M}|^{3}) in each round. While the additional computation complexity at each device i𝑖i is 𝒪​(1)𝒪1\mathcal{O}(1) in each round, due to the estimation of ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} and βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i}. For the signaling overhead, compared to the conventional FL, each scheduled device needs to send 3 extra scalars to the BS in each round (i.e., ρ^isubscript^𝜌𝑖\hat{\rho}_{i}, β^isubscript^𝛽𝑖\hat{\beta}_{i}, and Fi​(𝒘k−1Π)subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘1ΠF_{i}(\bm{w}_{k-1}^{\Pi})) as shown in step 16, which is negligible compared to sending the high-dimensional local updated model 𝒘i,ksubscript𝒘𝑖𝑘\bm{w}_{i,k}.

IV Experiment Results

In this section, we evaluate the performance of FL under the proposed scheduling policy.

IV-A Environment and FL Setups

Unless otherwise specified, we consider an FL system that consists of M=20𝑀20M=20 devices located in a cell of radius R=600𝑅600R=600 m and a BS located at the center of the cell. Assume that all devices are uniformly distributed in the cell at the beginning of each round to reflect mobility [15]. The wireless bandwidth is B=20𝐵20B=20 MHz, and the path loss exponent is α=3.76𝛼3.76\alpha=3.76. The transmit power of devices is set to be Pi=10subscript𝑃𝑖10P_{i}=10 dBm, and the power spectrum density of the additive Gaussian noise is N0=−114subscript𝑁0114N_{0}=-114 dBm/MHz.

We evaluate the training performance of the proposed policy under two well-known learning tasks, the MNIST dataset [31] for handwritten digits classification and the CIFAR-10 dataset [32] for image classification. The MNIST dataset has 60,000 training images and 10,000 testing images of the 10 digits, and the CIFAR-10 dataset has 50,000 training images and 10,000 images of 10 types of objects. We accept the common assumption that each device has equal amount of training data samples and the local training datasets are non-overlapping with each other[20, 15]. Different training data distributions are considered, including i.i.d. case and non-i.i.d. cases. For the i.i.d. dataset, the original training dataset is randomly partitioned into 20 pieces and each device is assigned a piece. While for the non-i.i.d. cases, the original training dataset is first partitioned into 10 pieces according to the label, and each piece with the same label is then randomly partitioned into 2​l2𝑙2l shards (i.e., 20​l20𝑙20l shards in total). Finally, each device is assigned l𝑙l shards with different labels. The parameter l𝑙l captures the non-i.i.d. level of local datasets, where smaller l𝑙l corresponds to a higher non-i.i.d. level. Following [22, 33], we train a multilayer perceptron (MLP) model with a single hidden layer with 64 nodes, and use ReLU activation. The mini-batch size is set to be 128 for the local model update, and each scheduled device performs τ=5𝜏5\tau=5 local updates between two adjacent global aggregations. The learning rate η𝜂\eta is set to be 0.010.010.01 for MNIST and 0.020.020.02 for CIFAR-10. The MLP model has 50,816 multiply-and-accumulate (MAC) operations for MNIST. Assuming that all devices are of the same kind, having maximum CPU frequency of 1 GHz/s and can process one MAC operation in each CPU cycle, and thus we set a=0.5𝑎0.5a=0.5 ms/sample and further set μ=1a𝜇1𝑎\mu=\frac{1}{a} for the computation latency model [34]. The total training time budget T𝑇T is set to be 606060 seconds for MNIST and 200200200 seconds for CIFAR-10, and the initial values of ρ^isubscript^𝜌𝑖\hat{\rho}_{i}, β^isubscript^𝛽𝑖\hat{\beta}_{i}, and δ^isubscript^𝛿𝑖\hat{\delta}_{i} are 1.5, 12, and 2, respectively.

IV-B Evaluation of the Fast Converge Scheduling Policy

As mentioned in Section III.C, the system parameter φ𝜑\varphi needs to be determined through experiments, thus we study the effects of φ𝜑\varphi first. Fig. 2(a), (c) show the highest achievable accuracy within the training time budget v.s. the value of φ𝜑\varphi on MNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively, and Fig. 2(b), (d) show the average number of scheduled devices v.s. the value of φ𝜑\varphi on MNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively. From Fig. 2(b), (d), we notice that the proposed fast converge scheduling policy (denoted by FC) schedules more devices with larger φ𝜑\varphi. This finding is due to the following reason. According to Alg. 2, FC schedules devices by minimizing the objective function of P4, in which the term B​(Π)𝐵ΠB(\Pi) is not related to φ𝜑\varphi and other terms decrease with φ𝜑\varphi. Therefore, minimizing B​(Π)𝐵ΠB(\Pi) is more important with larger φ𝜑\varphi, which requires scheduling more devices. Furthermore, Fig. 2(a) shows that when φ=0.05𝜑0.05\varphi=0.05, FC has the best performance in terms of the highest achievable accuracy, which is 92.3%, 90.6%, and 89.0% for i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. data distributions with l=2𝑙2l=2 and l=1𝑙1l=1 on MNIST. While on CIFAR-10, φ=0.05𝜑0.05\varphi=0.05 achieves good performance as shown in Fig. 2(c), confirming that FC adapts to different datasets. Therefore, we set φ=0.05𝜑0.05\varphi=0.05 in the following experiments. Moreover, it is shown in Fig. 2(a), (c) that the convergence performance is not sensitive to the value of φ𝜑\varphi as long as 0.02≤φ≤0.50.02𝜑0.50.02\leq\varphi\leq 0.5, indicating that large step can be taken to reduce the searching cost for φ𝜑\varphi in practice. The performance of the proposed policy with estimation errors of the computation latency ti,kcpsubscriptsuperscript𝑡cp𝑖𝑘t^{\text{cp}}_{i,k} and the channel state hi,ksubscriptℎ𝑖𝑘h_{i,k} is also reported in Fig. 2. We simulate the estimation error by an Gaussian distribution with 00 mean and α​ti,kcp𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑡cp𝑖𝑘\alpha t^{\text{cp}}_{i,k} or α​hi,k𝛼subscriptℎ𝑖𝑘\alpha h_{i,k} standard deviation for ti,kcpsubscriptsuperscript𝑡cp𝑖𝑘t^{\text{cp}}_{i,k} or hi,ksubscriptℎ𝑖𝑘h_{i,k}, repectively, where ti,kcpsubscriptsuperscript𝑡cp𝑖𝑘t^{\text{cp}}_{i,k} and hi,ksubscriptℎ𝑖𝑘h_{i,k} is the true value. The average number of scheduled devices with estimation errors is almost the same as that without estimation error as shown in Fig. 2(b), (d), indicating that the performance loss is mostly caused by the round latency. The main reason for the increasing round latency is that the estimation errors can cause the device scheduling algorithm (Alg. 2) to schedule inappropriate devices. Nevertheless, Fig. 2(a), (c) show that the proposed policy is robust to estimation errors.

Then the instantaneous results of FC on MNIST are shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3(a) shows the model accuracy of 𝒘kΠsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘Π\bm{w}_{k}^{\Pi} and 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}} on the testing dataset v.s. the number of rounds. Note that the accuracy of 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}} is mostly higher than that of 𝒘kΠsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘Π\bm{w}_{k}^{\Pi} under the same data distribution, which is consistent with the definition of 𝒘~~𝒘\tilde{\bm{w}}. We also notice that the number of scheduled devices increases with the non-i.i.d. level due to the higher values of the estimated ρ𝜌\rho, β𝛽\beta, and δ𝛿\delta. For l=1𝑙1l=1 and l=2𝑙2l=2 datasets, since the local datasets of different devices are non-i.i.d., differences between the local updated models are greater than that of the i.i.d. dataset, and thus the value of δ𝛿\delta that characterizes the differences between model updates is higher. Similar results can be observed for β𝛽\beta and ρ𝜌\rho, indicating that the loss function is less smooth and convex for the non-i.i.d. datasets. Further, since ρ𝜌\rho, β𝛽\beta, and δ𝛿\delta tend to decrease during the training as shown by Fig. 3(d), (e), and (f), respectively, FC schedules more devices in the beginning of the training process, which helps FL to converge faster [33].

IV-C Comparison of Different Scheduling Policies

To show the effectiveness of the convergence analysis, we compare FC with a set of baseline policies that schedule fixed numbers of devices (i.e., remove steps 8-9 in Alg. 2, and stop scheduling new devices until reaching the fixed number).

Fig. 4 shows the highest achievable accuracy of FC, the baseline policies, and centralized training on MNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively. The result of centralized training can be treated as the upper bound of performance, where the central trainer is assumed to have 20 times stronger computation capability compared to the devices and all training data have been aggregated to the central trainer. We notice that for the baseline policies, scheduling either too few or too many devices degrades the model accuracy for l=1𝑙1l=1 and l=2𝑙2l=2 on MNIST and all three cases on CIFAR-10. The reason is the trade-off between the latency per round and the number of the rounds, that is: scheduling more devices can potentially reduce the number of required rounds to attain a fixed accuracy but with larger latency per round, while scheduling fewer devices can reduce the latency per round but with slower convergence rate w.r.t. the number of rounds. For FC, since the number of scheduled devices can be optimized, there is only one point for each dataset in the figure which actually corresponds to the average number of scheduled devices. As shown in Fig. 4, FC performs close to the optimal points for all data distributions, because the proposed FC achieves a good trade-off between the latency per round and the number of rounds. Moreover, the optimal number of scheduled devices increases with the non-i.i.d. level, indicating that a fixed scheduling policy cannot adapt to all different distributions of the datasets.

Furthermore, we compare FC with 4 other baseline policies. The first baseline is the random scheduling policy (denoted by RD) with the empirically optimal number of scheduled devices for l=2𝑙2l=2 on MNIST, which is NRD=3subscript𝑁RD3N_{\text{RD}}=3. The second one is the proportional fair policy (denoted by PF) proposed in [25] that schedules NPFsubscript𝑁PFN_{\text{PF}} devices with the best instantaneous channel conditions out of all M𝑀M devices, where we set NPF=NRDsubscript𝑁PFsubscript𝑁RDN_{\text{PF}}=N_{\text{RD}} in the experiments. The third one is the client selection policy proposed in [23], which iteratively schedules the device that consumes the least time in local model updating and uploading, until reaching a preset time threshold Th,CSsubscript𝑇hCST_{\text{h},\text{CS}}, and all scheduled devices are allocated equal bandwidth. Here we use two different thresholds Th,CSlow=0.4superscriptsubscript𝑇hCSlow0.4T_{\text{h},\text{CS}}^{\text{low}}=0.4 second and Th,CShigh=1.5superscriptsubscript𝑇hCShigh1.5T_{\text{h},\text{CS}}^{\text{high}}=1.5 second, namely CS-l and CS-h, to adapt to various data distributions and cell radius. The last one is the joint scheduling and resource allocation policy proposed in [26] that optimizes the asymptotic convergence performance by scheduling as many devices as possible within a given time threshold Th,ASsubscript𝑇hAST_{\text{h},\text{AS}}. In the experiments, we set Th,ASlow=0.4superscriptsubscript𝑇hASlow0.4T_{\text{h},\text{AS}}^{\text{low}}=0.4 second and Th,AShigh=1.5superscriptsubscript𝑇hAShigh1.5T_{\text{h},\text{AS}}^{\text{high}}=1.5 second for AS-l and AS-h, respectively.

The convergence performances w.r.t. time on MNIST under different scheduling policies are reported in Fig. 5(a) and (c) for R=600𝑅600R=600 with l=1𝑙1l=1 dataset and R=200𝑅200R=200 with i.i.d. dataset, respectively. Fig. 5(b) and (d) show the corresponding average number of scheduled devices and average latency per round. For R=600𝑅600R=600 m with l=1𝑙1l=1 dataset, we notice that FC reaches 80% test accuracy after 17.35 seconds of training, while PF needs 54.71 seconds to attain the same accuracy and other policies are even slower. Also note that under the given training time budget T=60𝑇60T=60 seconds, the highest achievable accuracy is 89.0% under FC, which is 9.0%, 6.4%, 9.2%, and 8.1% higher than RD, PF, CL-l, and AS-l, respectively. For R=200𝑅200R=200 m with i.i.d. dataset, FC attains 92.6% test accuracy within the training time budget, exceeds RD, PF, CL-h, and AS-h over 2.1%, 2.0%, 2.4%, and 2.5%, respectively. The advantage of FC is twofold: Firstly, FC schedules the devices with better channel conditions and computation capabilities according to Alg. 2, and thus can reduce the per round latency compared to RD and PF. For example, for R=600𝑅600R=600 m with l=1𝑙1l=1 dataset, FC is able to schedule on average 6.26 devices within 0.62 second per round while PF needs 0.94 second for only 3 devices as shown in Fig. 5(b). Secondly, FC achieves a better trade-off between the latency per round and the number of required rounds. Since the time thresholds for CS-l, CS-h, AS-l, and AS-h are fixed, they can hardly adapt to various data distributions and cell radius. As shown in Fig. 5(a) and (b), CS-l and AS-l schedule too few devices due to the low time threshold, and thus converge slower than FC for R=600𝑅600R=600 m with l=1𝑙1l=1 dataset. While Fig. 5(c) and (d) show that CS-h and AS-h converge slower than FC for R=200𝑅200R=200 m with i.i.d. dataset because of scheduling too many devices.

Table III summarizes the highest achievable accuracy on MNIST and CIFAR-10 under different data distributions and cell radius. Each item gives the results of l=1𝑙1l=1, l=2𝑙2l=2, and i.i.d. datasets on MNIST and l=2𝑙2l=2, l=5𝑙5l=5, and i.i.d. datasets on CIFAR-10, respectively. It is shown that FC adapts to different system settings and datasets, achieving the highest accuracy under most settings. Although CS-l, CS-h, AS-l, and AS-h have similar or even higher (but no more than 0.2%) accuracy compared to FC under some settings (e.g., R=200𝑅200R=200 m with l=2𝑙2l=2 on MNIST for CS-l and AS-l, R=1000𝑅1000R=1000 m with l=1𝑙1l=1 on MNIST for CS-h and AS-h, and R=1000𝑅1000R=1000 m with l=5𝑙5l=5 on CIFAR-10 for CS-h), the accuracy degrades notably under other settings, indicating that CS-l, CS-h, AS-l, and AS-h are not flexible or robust. Since the optimal number of scheduled devices and the per round latency vary under different system settings, choosing the optimal Thsubscript𝑇hT_{\text{h}} for CS and AS accordingly is neither efficient nor practical for wireless FL.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we have studied a joint bandwidth allocation and scheduling problem to optimize the convergence rate of FL w.r.t. time. We derive a convergence bound of FL to characterize the impact of device scheduling, based on which a joint bandwidth allocation and scheduling policy has been proposed. The proposed FC policy achieves a desirable trade-off between the latency per round and the number of required rounds, in order to minimize the global loss function of the obtained model parameter under a given training time budget. The experiments reveal that the optimal number of scheduled devices increases with the non-i.i.d. level of local datasets. In addition, the proposed FC policy can schedule near-optimal number of devices according to the learned loss function characteristics, gradient characteristics and system dynamics, and outperforms state-of-the-art baseline scheduling policies under different data distributions and cell radius. In the future, FL systems with heterogenous device computation capabilities and resource constraints can be considered, where joint optimization of the batch size, the number of local updates, and the device scheduling policy can be studied.

If any device has finished the whole local model update process earlier than other devices, we can reallocate some bandwidth from that device to other slower devices. Therefore, the optimal solution of P2 can be achieved if and only if all bandwidth is allocated and all scheduled devices have the same finishing time. Solving (13) directly leads to Theorem 1.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 2

Based on Assumption 1, the definition of F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F(\bm{w}), and triangle inequality, we immediately have the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

If Assumption 1 holds, then F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\bm{w}) is convex, ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, and β𝛽\beta-smooth.

Due to that F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F(\bm{w}) is β𝛽\beta-smooth, we have

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 3

First, we have the following lemma.

Lemma 2.

If the following conditions hold:

  1. 1.

    η≤1β𝜂1𝛽\eta\leq\frac{1}{\beta}

  2. 2.

    η​φ−ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)τ​ϵ2>0𝜂𝜑𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π𝜏superscriptitalic-ϵ20\eta\varphi-\frac{\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)}{\tau\epsilon^{2}}>0

  4. 4.

    F​(𝒘KΠ)−F​(𝒘∗)≥ϵ𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝐾𝐹superscript𝒘italic-ϵF(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{K})-F(\bm{w}^{*})\geq\epsilon

for some ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, φ≜ω​(1−β​η2)≜𝜑𝜔1𝛽𝜂2\varphi\triangleq\omega\left(1-\frac{\beta\eta}{2}\right) and ω≜mink​1∥𝐰kΠ−𝐰∗∥≜𝜔subscriptmin𝑘1delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscript𝐰Π𝑘superscript𝐰\omega\triangleq{\rm{min}}_{k}\frac{1}{\left\lVert\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k}-\bm{w}^{*}\right\rVert}, then the global loss function of wireless FL can be bounded by

𝔼​{1F​(𝒘KΠ)−F​(𝒘∗)}≥K​(η​φ​τ−ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)ϵ2),𝔼1𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝐾𝐹superscript𝒘𝐾𝜂𝜑𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Πsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\frac{1}{F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{K})-F(\bm{w}^{*})}\right\}\geq K\left(\eta\varphi\tau-\frac{\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)}{\epsilon^{2}}\right), (21)

where the expectation is taken over the randomness over ΠΠ\Pi.

Proof.

First, we define θk=F​(v→k)−F​(𝒘∗)subscript𝜃𝑘𝐹subscript→𝑣𝑘𝐹superscript𝒘\theta_{k}=F(\vec{v}_{k})-F(\bm{w}^{*}). According to (30) in [20], we have

∎

Based on Lemma 2, we can now proof Theorem 3. Since the condition η≤1β𝜂1𝛽\eta\leq\frac{1}{\beta} in Theorem 3, the first condition in Lemma 2 is always satisfied.

When ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)=0𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π0\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)=0, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon can be chosen arbitrarily small to satisfy conditions 2-4 in Lemma 2. Because the right hand side of (11) and (31) is equal when ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)=0𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π0\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)=0, Theorem 3 is directly from Lemma 2.

When ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)>0𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π0\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)>0, we consider the right hand side of (31) and let

1ϵ0=K​(η​φ​τ−ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)ϵ02).1subscriptitalic-ϵ0𝐾𝜂𝜑𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Πsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}}=K\left(\eta\varphi\tau-\frac{\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)}{\epsilon_{0}^{2}}\right). (32)

Solving for ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0} and ignoring the negative solution, we have

ϵ0=1+1+4​η​φ​K2​τ​(ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π))2​η​φ​K​τ.subscriptitalic-ϵ0114𝜂𝜑superscript𝐾2𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π2𝜂𝜑𝐾𝜏\epsilon_{0}=\frac{1+\sqrt{1+4\eta\varphi K^{2}\tau\left(\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)\right)}}{2\eta\varphi K\tau}. (33)

Since ϵ0>0subscriptitalic-ϵ00\epsilon_{0}>0, η​φ​τ−ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)ϵ02>0𝜂𝜑𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Πsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ020\eta\varphi\tau-\frac{\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)}{\epsilon_{0}^{2}}>0 based on (32). We note that η​φ​τ−ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)ϵ2𝜂𝜑𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Πsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2\eta\varphi\tau-\frac{\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)}{\epsilon^{2}} increases with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon when ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)>0𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π0\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)>0, hence condition 2 in Lemma 2 is satisfied for any ϵ>ϵ0italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon>\epsilon_{0}.

Suppose that there exists ϵ>ϵ0italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon>\epsilon_{0} satisfying conditions 3 and 4 in Lemma 2. Then all the conditions in Lemma 2 are satisfied, and we have

𝔼​{1F​(𝒘KΠ)−F​(𝒘∗)}𝔼1𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝐾𝐹superscript𝒘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\frac{1}{F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{K})-F(\bm{w}^{*})}\right\} ≥K​(η​φ​τ−ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)ϵ2)≥K​(η​φ​τ−ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)ϵ02)=1ϵ0.absent𝐾𝜂𝜑𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Πsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐾𝜂𝜑𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Πsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ021subscriptitalic-ϵ0\displaystyle\geq K\left(\eta\varphi\tau-\frac{\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)}{\epsilon^{2}}\right)\geq K\left(\eta\varphi\tau-\frac{\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)}{\epsilon_{0}^{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}}. It contradicts with condition 4 in Lemma 2, and thus there does not exist ϵ>ϵ0italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon>\epsilon_{0} that satisfy both conditions 3 and 4 in Lemma 2. Therefore, either ∃k𝑘\exists k that satisfies F​(𝒗k)−F​(𝒘∗)≤ϵ0𝐹subscript𝒗𝑘𝐹superscript𝒘subscriptitalic-ϵ0F(\bm{v}_{k})-F(\bm{w}^{*})\leq\epsilon_{0} or F​(𝒗k)−F​(𝒘∗)≤ϵ0𝐹subscript𝒗𝑘𝐹superscript𝒘subscriptitalic-ϵ0F(\bm{v}_{k})-F(\bm{w}^{*})\leq\epsilon_{0}. Then we have

min​{mink=1,2,…,K​F​(𝐯k);F​(𝐰KΠ)}−F​(𝒘∗)≤ϵ0.min𝑘12…𝐾minFsubscript𝐯kFsubscriptsuperscript𝐰ΠK𝐹superscript𝒘subscriptitalic-ϵ0{\rm min}\left\{\underset{k=1,2,\dots,K}{\rm min}F(\bm{v}_{k});F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{K})\right\}-F(\bm{w}^{*})\leq\epsilon_{0}. (35)

Based on Theorem 2 and Theorem 1 in [20], we have 𝔼​{F​(𝒘kΠ)}≤F​(𝒗k)+ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π)𝔼𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝒘Π𝑘𝐹subscript𝒗𝑘𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π\mathbb{E}\{F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k})\}\leq F(\bm{v}_{k})+\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi) for any k𝑘k. Substituting into (35) yields

mink=1,2,…,K​𝔼​{F​(𝐰kΠ)−F​(𝐰∗)}≤ϵ0+ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π).𝑘12…𝐾min𝔼Fsubscriptsuperscript𝐰ΠkFsuperscript𝐰subscriptitalic-ϵ0𝜌h𝜏BΠ\underset{k=1,2,\dots,K}{\rm min}\mathbb{E}\left\{F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k})-F(\bm{w}^{*})\right\}\leq\epsilon_{0}+\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi). (36)

Then based on the Jensen’s inequality and the convexity of f​(x)=1x𝑓𝑥1𝑥f(x)=\frac{1}{x}, we have

𝔼​{1mink=1,2,…,K​F​(𝐰kΠ)−F​(𝐰∗)}𝔼1𝑘12…𝐾minFsubscriptsuperscript𝐰ΠkFsuperscript𝐰\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\frac{1}{\underset{k=1,2,\dots,K}{\rm min}F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k})-F(\bm{w}^{*})}\right\} ≥1𝔼​{mink=1,2,…,K​F​(𝐰kΠ)−F​(𝐰∗)}absent1𝔼𝑘12…𝐾minFsubscriptsuperscript𝐰ΠkFsuperscript𝐰\displaystyle\geq\frac{1}{\mathbb{E}\left\{\underset{k=1,2,\dots,K}{\rm min}F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k})-F(\bm{w}^{*})\right\}}
≥1mink=1,2,…,K​𝔼​{F​(𝐰kΠ)−F​(𝐰∗)}absent1𝑘12…𝐾min𝔼Fsubscriptsuperscript𝐰ΠkFsuperscript𝐰\displaystyle\geq\frac{1}{\underset{k=1,2,\dots,K}{\rm min}\mathbb{E}\left\{F(\bm{w}^{\Pi}_{k})-F(\bm{w}^{*})\right\}}
≥1ϵ0+ρ​h​(τ)+B​(Π).absent1subscriptitalic-ϵ0𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐵Π\displaystyle\geq\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}+\rho h(\tau)+B(\Pi)}. (37)

Combine (37) with the definition of F​(𝒘~)𝐹~𝒘F(\tilde{\bm{w}}) (i.e., (7)) and (33), we have Theorem 3 proved.
